project.name: foo-tools
project.oneliner: A collection of useful tools for users of glftpd.
project.description:
foo-tools is a collection of useful tools for
users of glftpd. It contains, among other things,
an entry bouncer, alternative gl_spy
implemetations, and tools for post-processing
uploads.

project.name: maildirpop3d

recent_releases.changelog: The path is now searched for the qmail-pop3d program if the full path is not supplied.

project.oneliner: A Qmail extension supporting multiple POP mailboxes for a single shell account.
project.description:
maildirpop3d offers multiple POP mailboxes (with
distinct passwords) controlled by a single shell
account. It is a checkpassword replacement, and
sits between qmail-popup and qmail-pop3d. If it
sees a username like "joe-foo", and 
~joe/Maildir-foo is a directory, it invokes
qmail-pop3d (as joe) on ~joe/Maildir-foo.
maildirpasswd (included) is then invoked by joe to
set the password for the joe-foo mailbox. The
password is then encrypted and stored.

project.name: Module-Format

recent_releases.changelog: A bug was fixed with guessing the "unix" format (e.g: "Foo/Bar/Baz.pm"). Keywords and resources were added to the META.yml.

project.oneliner: Convert and manipulate strings representing Perl modules and CPAN distributions.
project.description: Perl modules are notated in many different formats: "Foo/Bar/Baz.pm", "Foo::Bar", "Foo-Bar", etc. Module-Format allows one to take a list of modules in any format (including mixed ones) and output it in a consistent format that can be input to an installation program or an information querier.

project.name: portell

recent_releases.changelog:
This release runs under BSD systems other than FreeBSD and autocreates
the database.

project.description:
portell is a program that allows BSD users to
view the description as given in its pkg-descr or pkg/DESCR file for a specific package. If you want to know what the program "foo" is, then you can type "portell foo" from any directory, and portell will instantly dump its description file to your display.

project.name: Pwdrc

recent_releases.changelog:
recurse_pwdrc() has been added in the set of
definable functions, and it is called each time
the user walks into a sub-directory. The
"todo_remider" cookbook has been improved. It
doesn't conflict anymore if used in multiple
directories, and it supports the shuffling of the
output to increase the user's attention.

New cookbooks has been added. "automount" automounts a /mnt directory
without autofs. "cvsroot" sets your CVS environment variables.
"gqview_imgdir" opens gqview when you enter an image directory.
"todo_reminder" prints a TODO file. "newmail_mutt_Z" opens mutt if new
messages have arrived.

project.oneliner: Executes a set of commands when you walk in a directory with "cd".
project.description:
Pwdrc executes a set of commands each time you
walk in a directory with "cd". You can associate a
different set of commands to each directory. Each
time you walk in a directory the file
.`whoami`_pwdrc is read and executed (if it
exists), thus if your user name is "foo", your
pwdrc file is ".foo_pwdrc".

project.name: petopt

recent_releases.changelog: This release adds boolean variables (--with(out)-X and --(dis)enable-X).

project.oneliner: C command line argument parsing library
project.description: Petopt is a free command line argument parsing library that handles short (-v) and long (--foo-bar) options. It supports abbreviated long options and should be pretty easy to use.

project.name: dup-label
project.oneliner: A tool that duplicates a Sun Solaris disk label.
project.description:
dup-label copies a label from one disk on a Solaris system to 
another, but if the source disk's ASCII label was "foo" and 
the destination disk's ASCII label was "bar", then dup-label 
will duplicate partitioning, but also produce an ASCII label of 
"foo, was: bar".  This may prove less puzzling than current 
other offerings to future 
admins, when they otherwise would find that a disk that has 
Seagate written on the outside, says Maxtor in sun format.

project.name: libfssearch

recent_releases.changelog:
New methods were added, overall speed was improved, minor bugs were fixed, the
documentation was updated, and other improvements were made.

project.oneliner: A file system traversal library with callback functionality.
project.description:
libfssearch is a C++ library that provides file and directory traversal
functionality. Given a base directory, it will traverse the tree rooted at that
directory in depth-first order, invoking a callback function for each file or
directory found. It is basically a C++ version of the Unix command, "find -exec
foo". It has been tested on Solaris and Linux.

project.name: glark

recent_releases.changelog:
Short option names (e.g., --inv instead of
--invert-match) are now supported. A significant
amount of code was rewritten for better execution
speed.

Support was added for --with-fullname,
--without-fullname, --with-basename, and
--without-basename, which limit the files to be
searched to those with full and base names
matching the regular expression given. A bug with
--after and --before taking non-percentage
arguments was fixed.

A bug was fixed with the --and option, which was
previously getting the closest paired match, not
the farthest one within the maximum distance.
Tests were added, and significant refactoring was
done.

A bug in the --invert-match (-v) option was fixed.
A check for recursive cycles caused by links was
added.
The --label option has been fixed to take any string, instead of just one word. Warning output for unknown options has been fixed.

project.oneliner: A grep-like tool for searching text files.
project.description: glark offers grep-like searching of text files, with very powerful, complex regular expressions (e.g., "/foo\w+/ and /bar[^\d]*baz$/ within 4 lines of each other"). It also highlights the matches, displays context (preceding and succeeding lines), does case-insensitive matches, and automatic exclusion of non-text files. It supports most options from the GNU version of grep.

project.name: PCJBot

recent_releases.changelog: Everything has been POE-ised, and there are new plugins.
The math module now handles decimals. Caching in the weather module was fixed.
Better documentation, caching weather, minimum cycle time for cron, cron improvements, and automatically creates the database if required.

project.oneliner: A Jabber conference bot written in Perl with PCJ.
project.description:
PCJBot is a Jabber bot written in Perl with PCJ.
It can do various things on a Jabber chat channel.
It remembers "foo is bar" facts and does other
things with plugins. Plugins include Bloglines,
Cron, DNS, Weather, Math, Spellcheck, Seen, and URL.
